questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

Negative acute phase reactants are substances whose serum concentrations decrease in response to systemic inflammation. Albumin is one of the well-recognized negative acute phase reactants. Its levels fall during acute phase response as resources are shifted to produce more critical positive reactants that help in the defense and repair processes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haptoglobin: This is a positive acute phase reactant, which increases in response to inflammation.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Also a positive acute phase reactant, often increases in states of inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. C-reactive protein: A classic positive acute phase reactant, it increases dramatically in response to inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

In a patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the immediate management involves FLIP Therapy (fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy and Potassium management). This patient's blood glucose is significantly elevated, and the presence of ketones indicates DKA, which is a medical emergency.

 

1. Fluids: The initial step is to administer intravenous (IV) fluids to correct dehydration and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. The typical approach involves giving isotonic saline (0.9% sodium chloride) at a rate of 10-20 mL/kg/hr (2-3L) for the first 2-3 hours. This helps to correct hypovolemia, improve perfusion, and begin to lower blood glucose levels.

 

Criteria for fluid management: After the initial two to three hours of treatment, switch from initial fluids (typically normal saline) to half normal saline for ongoing maintenance. If capillary blood glucose (CBG) drops below 300 mg/dL, and specifically if it falls below 250 mg/dL, add 5% dextrose water to the regimen. The purpose of adding dextrose is to maintain a target CBG range of 200 to 300 mg/dL. This range helps prevent hypoglycemia, which is a critical concern in the management process.

 

2. Insulin: Insulin therapy is crucial to halt ketogenesis and reduce blood glucose levels. After 1 hr of fluid start insulin. The recommended protocol for DKA involves IV regular insulin because of its rapid onset and short duration of action. The insulin regimen follows a fixed dose insulin infusion (FDII) approach. This helps to normalize blood glucose and ketone levels efficiently.

 

First option: Continuous infusion at 0.15 units/kg/hour.

 

Second option (more commonly used): Administer a 0.1 units/kg bolus, followed by a 0.1 units/kg/hour infusion.

 

IV regular insulin is preferred over subcutaneous (SC) insulin in emergency settings like DKA due to its predictable absorption and ability to be titrated easily based on frequent blood glucose monitoring.

 

Adjustments Based on Blood Glucose Levels: Monitor capillary blood glucose (CBG). If CBG drops below 300 mg/dL, reduce the insulin infusion to half the dose (0.05 units/kg/hour).

 

Criteria for Stopping Insulin Infusion: Insulin infusion can be stopped ONLY when the patient tolerates oral feeds without vomiting or abdominal pain. Other criteria include resolution of ketoacidosis, negative or trace positive plasma ketones, and an anion gap less than 12, pH more than 7.3 and serum bicarbonate more than 18. Transition to subcutaneous insulin upon meeting these criteria.

 

Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

The correct choice is B, Dexamethasone, because the symptoms described (fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates) suggest the patient may be experiencing differentiation syndrome, which can occur following the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with agents like Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by such symptoms and can improve with the administration of Dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is also used intrathecally in children for treating Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), indicating its relevance in managing severe inflammatory reactions in hematological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: This option is incorrect as Cytarabine is primarily used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia and not specifically indicated for the management of differentiation syndrome in APML.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Incorrect because Doxorubicin is utilized for its efficacy against various cancers including Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the breast, and thyroid but is not suitable for treating differentiation syndrome in APML. It is also known for its cardiotoxic effects.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Incorrect as it is not recommended in the treatment regimen for APML and does not address the immediate complications of differentiation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

 

Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intrinsic asthma

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is often associated with nasal polyps. This type of asthma does not have an allergic or atopic component and tends to develop in adulthood. Intrinsic asthma is characterized by a non-IgE mediated pathway involving eosinophils and neutrophils, often triggered by non-allergic factors such as viral infections, stress, or exercise. Nasal polyps in this context are linked to chronic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages, common in non-allergic forms of asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brittle asthma: This is a term used to describe a severe form of asthma where patients experience frequent, severe exacerbations. While serious, it does not specifically correlate with the presence of nasal polyps more than other types of asthma.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Known as allergic asthma, it is mediated by IgE and typically involves allergen triggers like pollen, dust mites, and molds. Nasal polyps are less commonly associated with this subtype compared to intrinsic asthma.

 

Option D. Exercise-induced asthma: This condition, characterized by bronchoconstriction triggered by physical activity, is not typically associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Pulmonology/Asthma/Chap 287

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

choices.text: SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inappropriately concentrated urine.
SIADH can be caused by medications, pulmonary diseases, or malignancies, particularly small cell lung cancer.
Patients with SIADH typically present with hypovolemia and significant edema
Treatment of SIADH includes fluid restriction and addressing the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and recent hospital admission for pneumonia presents with symptoms of confusion, fatigue, and mild nausea. The clinical team suspects syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Which statement about SIADH is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Patients with SIADH typically present with hypovolemia and significant edema.

 

Explanation:

 

SIADH is a disorder characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leading to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and concentrated urine despite low serum osmolality. It is commonly associated with conditions such as malignancies (especially small cell lung cancer), pulmonary diseases, and medications like antidepressants and antipsychotics. Patients with SIADH are usually euvolemic, without signs of hypovolemia or significant edema, as the retained water is distributed evenly within the body compartments without causing overt fluid overload.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inappropriately concentrated urine.
This statement is correct as it describes the hallmark findings in SIADH, where despite low serum osmolality, the kidneys fail to dilute the urine, leading to continued water retention and worsening hyponatremia.

 

Option B. SIADH can be caused by medications, pulmonary diseases, or malignancies, particularly small cell lung cancer.
This statement is correct. SIADH is commonly linked to various conditions, including small cell lung cancer, certain infections, and drugs that increase ADH release or action.

 

Option D. Treatment of SIADH includes fluid restriction and addressing the underlying cause.
This statement is correct as management of SIADH focuses on restricting free water intake to reduce hyponatremia and treating the underlying condition, such as discontinuing an offending medication or addressing the primary disease process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and concentrated urine despite normal or elevated ADH levels. It commonly occurs in response to pulmonary diseases, malignancies, or medications. Patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic without significant edema, and management includes fluid restriction and treating the underlying cause. Recognizing the absence of hypovolemia and edema is crucial in differentiating SIADH from other causes of hyponatremia.

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

 

Approximate length of nasogastric tube is 120 -125cm     

 

How to confirm correct position of NG tube:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • x-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

 

 

XIPHISTERNUM

 

Place the tip of the nasogastric tube at the tip of the nose, then measure from the nose to the ear lobe & down to the tip of the Xiphisternum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus: This measurement is too long as it typically extends beyond the stomach, potentially reaching into the intestines.

 

Option C. Mouth to ear to umbilicus: This measurement is also incorrect and typically used for other medical estimations, not for NG tube placement.

 

Option D. Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus: Similar to option B, this measurement is excessively long for proper NG tube placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

 

The child's presentation of recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea (bulky, greasy stools) is indicative of cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to severe respiratory infections and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

In CF, thick mucus secretions can lead to blockages in various parts of the body. One of the common gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), where thickened stool causes obstruction in the distal part of the small intestine. This condition is seen more frequently in older children and adults with CF, especially after the introduction of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT).

 

The treatment of choice for distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), which primarily involves the use of laxatives like PEG (Polyethylene glycol) is effective because it works by osmotically drawing water into the intestine, which helps to soften the stool and promote bowel movements, thereby alleviating the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein losing enteropathy: This condition can occur in CF, but it is more common in the infantile period or up to 2 years of age due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. It is not a primary concern in a 10-year-old child with CF presenting with the given symptoms.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia is not typically seen in CF. Instead, CF patients often exhibit hyponatremia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss through sweat. This electrolyte imbalance is characteristic of CF.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse occurs after treatment: Rectal prolapse was historically a common manifestation of untreated CF in young children. However, with effective treatment, including pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, rectal prolapse is now rare and does not usually occur after treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALS


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs. The presence of both Babinski sign (an upper motor neuron sign) and absent deep tendon reflexes (a lower motor neuron sign), along with the chronic progression and lack of sensory/autonomic involvement, strongly points towards ALS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. MS: Multiple sclerosis typically involves sensory symptoms and demyelinating plaques visible on MRI, which are not described here.

 

Option C. GBS: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute condition with a rapid onset and is primarily a lower motor neuron disease without upper motor neuron signs like the Babinski reflex.

 

Option D. Tropical spastic paraparesis: This condition is associated with HTLV-1 infection and presents predominantly with upper motor neuron signs, not the mixed signs seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

 

Plexiform neurofibroma is seen in patients with NF1 commonly in the craniomaxillofacial region. Malignant transformation to MPNST (Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor) occurs in 3-16% patients and is the cause of mortality.

 

The mass typically appears as a "bag of worms" due to the involvement of multiple nerve branches.

 

Treatment is mainly surgical resection of the tumor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve palsy: This condition typically presents with asymmetrical facial movement and weakness but does not cause mass-like growths.

 

Option B. Masticator space abscess: Characterized by swelling and pain, usually due to an infection, which would not cause the extensive, benign proliferative growth seen in the image.

 

Option D. Fibrous dysplasia: While it can cause bone deformity and asymmetry, it does not manifest as a soft, extensive mass typically seen in neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

choices.text: Blockage of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Blockage of the basilar artery
Blockage of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents with weakness and numbness on the right side of his face, along with weakness on the left side of his body. Examination reveals Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, constricted pupil, and decreased sweating), nystagmus (rapid involuntary eye movements), vertigo (dizziness), ataxia (loss of coordination), and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). He struggles to maintain his balance. What is the most frequent cause of this presentation? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Blockage of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Explanation:

 

The combination of symptoms in this patient strongly indicates lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is most commonly caused by a blockage (occlusion) of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The PICA supplies blood to the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, a region of the brainstem.

Lateral medullary syndrome presents with a characteristic pattern of symptoms. Ipsilateral (same-side) symptoms include facial weakness and numbness, ataxia, Horner's syndrome, and problems with swallowing and speech due to involvement of cranial nerves IX and X. Contralateral (opposite-side) symptoms include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blockage of the basilar artery: This would likely cause more severe and widespread brainstem dysfunction, often affecting both sides of the body.

 

Option C. Blockage of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery: This would result in similar symptoms but on the opposite side of the body, with left-sided facial weakness and right-sided body weakness.

 

OPTION D. Blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery: This would primarily affect the lateral pons region of the brainstem, causing a different set of symptoms than those seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Educational Objective

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is commonly caused by a blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), resulting in a specific combination of ipsilateral and contralateral neurological deficits. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

Clinical history is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Presence of low TSH with suspected hypothyroidism indicates loss of Log relationship of TSH & fT4 indicating a central cause. Administration of TRH improving TSH level indicates TRH deficiency which is mainly produced from the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Hyperthyroidism due to pituitary:  Cause like TSHoma is very rare. Also, symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are not present in the patient.

 

Option B. In pituitary disease: TSH will not improve with TRH administration as the gland is defective and cannot produce TSH.

 

Option D. Thyrotoxicosis symptoms are not present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

choices.text: Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

 

Fibrinolytic therapy, also known as thrombolytic therapy, is used to dissolve blood clots. Sometimes, it is necessary to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic drugs, especially in cases of excessive bleeding.

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA):

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is an antifibrinolytic agent. It works by binding to plasminogen competitively, which prevents plasminogen from binding to fibrin and being converted to plasmin. Plasmin is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fibrin in blood clots. By inhibiting this process, EACA effectively stops fibrinolysis and stabilizes blood clots, reducing the risk of bleeding.
  • Clinical Use: EACA is used to treat conditions where fibrinolysis is excessive, such as after the administration of fibrinolytic drugs (e.g., streptokinase, alteplase).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine: Protamine is used to neutralize the anticoagulant effects of heparin. It is not effective against fibrinolytic agents. Protamine binds to heparin, forming a stable complex that neutralizes heparin's anticoagulant activity.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is itself a fibrinolytic agent used to dissolve clots. It works by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which then breaks down fibrin. Streptokinase would increase fibrinolysis, not inhibit it.

 

Option C. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting thrombin and other clotting factors. It does not act as an antidote to fibrinolytic therapy. Heparin would actually increase the risk of bleeding if administered during fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the appropriate antidote for fibrinolytic therapy because it inhibits fibrinolysis by preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby stabilizing blood clots and reducing bleeding risks.

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

choices.text: Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP)
Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and night sweats. She denies any recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. On physical examination, she is febrile and has bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates and an HRCT scan reveals diffuse ground-glass opacities predominantly in the perihilar regions with small cystic changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer.  C) Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP)

 

Explanation:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP) is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV/AIDS or uncontrolled diabetes. The presence of diffuse ground-glass opacities (GGO) with small cystic changes, particularly in the perihilar regions on HRCT, is highly characteristic of PCP. The clinical presentation of dyspnea, non-productive cough, fever, and weight loss aligns with PCP, which is typically a subacute process. PCP often occurs in patients with weakened immune systems, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes, making this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Bacterial Pneumonia: Bacterial pneumonia generally presents with lobar or patchy infiltrates on imaging rather than diffuse ground-glass opacities and cystic changes. It is often associated with productive cough, high fever, and pleuritic chest pain, which were not prominently featured in this patient's case.

 

Option B) Pulmonary Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis may present with systemic symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss, similar to this patient. However, it typically shows upper lobe cavitary lesions or nodular infiltrates on imaging, not the diffuse GGO and cystic changes seen here, making it less likely.

 

Option D) Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): ARDS can cause diffuse ground-glass opacities; however, it is usually associated with an acute onset of symptoms following a known insult, such as sepsis, trauma, or aspiration. This patient’s subacute presentation and lack of a clear precipitating event make ARDS less probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS or uncontrolled diabetes, the presence of diffuse ground-glass opacities with small cystic changes on HRCT is highly indicative of Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP). Recognizing this imaging pattern is crucial for early diagnosis and management.

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis
Mutation in dynein arms
Antibodies against type-IV collagen

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency 

 

The gross specimen shown above has emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus, indicating panacinar emphysema. It is caused by a lack of alpha-1-antitrypsin.

 

The acini in this type are uniformly enlarged from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. The prefix "pan" denotes the entire acinus but not the entire lung. Panacinar emphysema, as opposed to centriacinar emphysema, is more common in the lower zones and anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases. This type of emphysema is linked to a lack of alpha 1-antitrypsin (AT).

 

 

 

A, Centriacinar emphysema. Central areas show marked emphysematous damage (E), surrounded by relatively spared alveolar spaces. B, Panacinar emphysema involving the entire pulmonary lobule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis:

 

  • Pathology: Cystic fibrosis is characterized by thick, sticky mucus production leading to recurrent lung infections and bronchiectasis, not emphysema.
  • Etiology: Caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to defective chloride channels.

 

Option C. Mutation in dynein arms:

 

Pathology: Dynein arm mutations are associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), which leads to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections, but not typically emphysema.

 

Option D. Antibodies against type-IV collagen:

 

Pathology: Associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, not emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder leading to a lack of AAT, which protects the lung tissue from elastase. The deficiency causes panacinar emphysema, characterized by uniform enlargement of acini, particularly in the lower lobes of the lung, and presents with chronic respiratory symptoms.

choices.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

 

Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.

 

RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).

 

 

 

  • TYPES OF RS CELLS:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Sclerosis - Hodgkin Lymphoma: This subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL) typically shows RS cells that are positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20, which is the opposite of what is seen in NLPHL.

 

Option B. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is characterized by small, mature-looking lymphocytes in the blood and bone marrow, not by the presence of RS cells or the nodular pattern seen in NLPHL.

 

Option C. T cell rich B cell lymphoma: This is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that could show a nodular pattern, but it lacks the characteristic L&H cells and the immunophenotypic profile seen in NLPHL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by the presence of L&H cells, vague nodular formation, and a specific immunophenotypic profile (CD20+, CD45+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-), which differentiates it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma and other lymphomas.

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

Explanation:

 

Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

 

Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.

 

Option C: Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bedside blood collection, label the samples, fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the patient
Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the Patient, Bedside blood collection, label the samples
Label the sample tubes, Bedside blood collection, fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the patient
Identify the Patient, Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Bedside blood collection, label the samples

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the Patient, Bedside blood collection, label the samples

 

The correct sequence for blood collection and sample handling in a clinical setting involves several critical steps to ensure patient safety and accurate test results. The sequence is as follows:

 

  1. Provisional diagnosis by the physician: This initial step involves the physician evaluating the patient and determining the necessary diagnostic tests.
  2. Fill the laboratory requisition forms: The healthcare staff or laboratory personnel must fill out the requisition forms based on the physician's diagnosis. This step is crucial because it ensures that the correct tests are requested and that the laboratory has all the necessary information to process the samples.
  3. Identify the Patient: Before collecting any samples, the healthcare staff must properly identify the patient. This step is vital to prevent any mix-up of samples, which could lead to incorrect diagnosis and treatment.
  4. Bedside blood collection: After confirming the patient's identity, the blood sample is collected at the bedside. Proper collection technique is essential to avoid contamination or sample degradation.
  5. Label the samples: Finally, the collected samples must be labeled accurately and immediately to ensure that they are correctly matched with the patient and the requested tests.

 

This sequence ensures that the right patient receives the correct test, and the results are reliable and accurate.

 

Educational objective:

 

Sequence:

 

Provisional diagnosis by the physician > Requisition forms are filled accordingly for test to the lab > patient is identified by the laboratory personnel/ health care staff > samples are collected and labeled appropriately.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

 

The patient presents with signs of paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, indicated by the ingestion of a high dose, deranged liver function tests (LFTs), and oliguria. Paracetamol overdose can lead to severe hepatotoxicity and acute liver failure.

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity. It works by replenishing glutathione stores, enhancing non-toxic metabolism of paracetamol, and reducing the formation of harmful metabolites. Early administration of N-acetylcysteine significantly reduces the risk of liver damage and improves outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is used in the management of shock to improve renal perfusion and cardiac output. It is not indicated in the treatment of paracetamol toxicity and does not address the underlying hepatic damage.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in the treatment of certain cholestatic liver diseases to improve bile flow. It does not play a role in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload conditions such as heart failure or renal failure. It does not address the hepatotoxicity caused by paracetamol overdose and is not part of the standard treatment protocol for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug.

 

A misbranded drug will not produce the effect due to reasons like lesser dose, different molecules in it etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: are drugs with improper labelling, labeling from a fictitious company, with improper storage guidelines, or even partly or wholly substituted by another drug or substance.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: are drugs with unwanted substance, for example iron in Paracetamol.

 

Option C. unethical drug: The term unethical drug is not used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug that is labeled as containing a certain amount of an active ingredient but actually contains a different amount is considered misbranded. Misbranded drugs can lead to ineffective treatment and potential harm due to incorrect dosing.

choices.text: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion, rapid breathing, and severe abdominal pain. Laboratory tests reveal a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with a serum bicarbonate level of 10 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause a high anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)

 

Explanation:

 

Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) is characterized by a normal anion gap (non-anion gap) metabolic acidosis. It results from the inability of the kidneys to excrete acid or reclaim bicarbonate, but it does not cause a significant accumulation of organic acids like lactate or ketones that would raise the anion gap. Therefore, RTA does not fit the profile of high anion gap acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
DKA is associated with high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of ketone bodies (acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate) in the blood. The resulting acidosis is typically accompanied by low bicarbonate levels, making DKA a classic cause of high anion gap acidosis.

 

Option B. Lactic Acidosis
Lactic acidosis is another common cause of high anion gap metabolic acidosis and occurs due to the accumulation of lactic acid, often seen in conditions like sepsis, shock, or tissue hypoxia. The elevated lactate levels contribute to a high anion gap and decreased bicarbonate levels.

 

Option D. Methanol Poisoning
Methanol poisoning leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites, such as formic acid. This condition presents with low bicarbonate levels and is typically associated with symptoms like visual disturbances and CNS depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs when acids accumulate in the body, such as in diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and toxin ingestions like methanol. Conditions like renal tubular acidosis, which do not involve significant acid accumulation, present with a normal anion gap despite having low bicarbonate levels. Understanding the difference between high and normal anion gap acidosis is essential in diagnosing and managing these metabolic disturbances.

choices.text: HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan)
Post surgery follow-up

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits her doctor's office complaining of recurrent pain in the right upper abdomen, nausea, and vomiting. She reports that these symptoms occur intermittently and have been happening for the past few months. Her doctor orders some tests, including an abdominal ultrasound, blood work, and a HIDA scan. After reviewing the results, the doctor diagnoses her with biliary dyskinesia. To determine the most effective treatment plan, the doctor considers various factors, including the patient's medical history, age, and overall health status. Which diagnostic test will be the least helpful in confirming the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) USG

 

The least helpful test in confirming the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia is the ultrasound (USG). While USG is valuable for visualizing gallstones and other structural abnormalities, it is not the optimal choice for diagnosing functional disorders like biliary dyskinesia or sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (SOD). Biliary dyskinesia often involves abnormal motility of the biliary system, which cannot be effectively assessed with USG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with manometry is considered the gold standard for diagnosing sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, which can overlap with or mimic symptoms of biliary dyskinesia. It allows direct visualization and measurement of the pressure within the biliary and pancreatic ducts.

 

Option B. A HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) is particularly useful for detecting biliary dyskinesia as it evaluates the function of the gallbladder and can show delayed biliary transit.

 

Option D. Post-surgery follow-up is essential for monitoring and managing potential complications or the persistence of symptoms related to SOD or biliary dyskinesia after treatment but does not help in initial confirmation of the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key point to remember is that USG, despite its utility in detecting structural anomalies in the biliary tract, is not effective in diagnosing functional disorders like biliary dyskinesia. Functional tests like the HIDA scan or ERCP with manometry are necessary for a definitive diagnosis of functional biliary disorders.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

 

Smoke contains multiple substances, of which the most significant component is carbon monoxide (CO). CO can cause both anemic hypoxia as well as histotoxic hypoxia, but predominant cause is anemic hypoxia. Mechanism of hypoxia by CO:

 

  • Anemic Hypoxia by CO: CO combines with hb to form COHb) producing anemic hypoxia (blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced)
  • Histotoxic Hypoxia by CO: While the primary impact of CO is on blood oxygen transport, the presence of COHb can also interfere with cellular respiration at the tissue level. COHb affects mitochondrial function and the electron transport chain, disrupting the cells' ability to utilize the oxygen that is delivered to them.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells can’t effectively use the available oxygen

due to interference with crucial cellular processes. CO causes histotoxic hypoxia also but the main cause of death is anemic hypoxia. A typical example of histotoxic hypoxia is cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B) Ischemic hypoxia results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock.

 

Option D) All of the above it is incorrect as CO may cause anemic and histotoxic hypoxia but not ischemic hypoxia

 

Educational objective

 

Anemic hypoxia

 

  • Anemic hypoxia is hypoxia  caused by the decreased O2-carrying capacity of blood. It can occur due to two reasons:
    • Hb concentration is low, or
    • Hb concentration may be normal, but it is not able to bind to O2. It can occur due to following conditions:
      • CO Poisoning: It has a higher affinity for Hb than O2 forming COHb.
      • Methemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin is a form of Hb where the iron is in the ferric state (Fe3+) instead of the normal ferrous state (Fe2+). Methemoglobin cannot bind to oxygen effectively.
      • Certain Genetic Hemoglobin Disorders altering the structure of Hb, e.g.

Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichodysplasia spinulosa: This is a rare viral infection associated with immunosuppression and does not typically present with the described clinical or histopathological features.

 

Option B. Condyloma accuminata: Caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), this condition presents as warty growths, typically on the genital and perianal regions, but it does not produce Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Option D. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis presents with ulcerative lesions rather than nodular papules and does not show the characteristic Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that presents with dome-shaped papules containing Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are diagnostic of this condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

 

This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase:

  • Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of tyrosine, an amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia Type I. However, Tyrosinemia Type I does not cause darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Option C. Homogentisate Dehydrogenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase, (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase) is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of homogentisic acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Alkaptonuria. In Alkaptonuria, homogentisic acid accumulates and causes the urine to turn black upon exposure to air. This is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.
     

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine, another amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU does not directly lead to darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Educational objective:

 

In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 286

choices.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life and plasma concentration doubles

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
 

In case of drugs following 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in a given time. Therefore, the half-life of the drug remains constant and the Clearance also remains constant.

 

Key points regarding first-order kinetics:
