  • Half-life remains constant: The half-life of the drug does not change with the dose. It remains constant because the fraction of the drug eliminated per unit time is constant.
  • Clearance remains constant: The clearance, which is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, remains constant.
  • Plasma concentration: When the dose is doubled, the plasma concentration of the drug also doubles because the rate of elimination is proportional to the concentration of the drug in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paracetamol

 

The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

 

Acetaminophen is the leading cause of drug-induced acute liver failure. The most common prescription drugs causing idiosyncratic injury (that is, drug toxicity unrelated to drug dosage) include antibiotics and, in particular, isoniazid, nonsteroidal analgesics, and anti-seizure.

 

  • Paracetamol poisoning is a medical emergency that requires prompt management to prevent serious liver damage and other complications. The general steps involved in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning:

 

1. Decontamination: If the ingestion of paracetamol occurred within the last 1-2 hours, activated charcoal can be given orally to reduce the absorption of paracetamol.

 

2. Treatment with antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC. is the specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It is most effective if given within 8 hours of ingestion of the overdose. NAC replenishes the depleted glutathione stores in the liver, which helps to prevent liver damage.

 

3. Monitoring and supportive care: Patients with paracetamol poisoning require close monitoring, particularly for liver and kidney function, electrolytes, blood glucose, and acid-base balance. Treatment with intravenous fluids, glucose and electrolytes may be necessary to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

 

RUMACK MATTHEW NOMOGRAM is used for monitoring:

 

 

4. Referral for specialist care: In severe cases of paracetamol poisoning, the patient may require specialist care in a hospital setting, including referral to a liver transplant center.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant cause of liver disease, including cirrhosis, but paracetamol is the leading cause of acute liver failure.

 

Option C. CCl4 (Carbon Tetrachloride): CCl4 is a chemical that can cause liver damage, but it is not a common cause of liver failure compared to paracetamol.

 

Option D. Pesticides: Certain pesticides can cause liver toxicity, but they are not as common a cause of liver failure as paracetamol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure, the mechanism involves free radical injury and so and it is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and close monitoring to prevent serious complications, including liver failure.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 11th edition, Pg 1635

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

choices.text: Blockage of the vas deferens
Abnormal sperm motility due to ciliary dysfunction
Genetic mutation affecting spermatogenesis

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the fertility clinic with a two-year history of unsuccessful attempts to conceive with his partner. He reports a long-standing history of recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and occasional episodes of productive cough. On further questioning, he also mentions episodes of nasal congestion and a previous diagnosis of situs inversus, where his heart is located on the right side of his chest. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Abnormal sperm motility due to ciliary dysfunction

 

Explanation:

 

Kartagener's syndrome, a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by defective cilia due to mutations affecting the dynein arms that are essential for ciliary movement. This dysfunction leads to ineffective clearing of mucus from the respiratory tract, resulting in recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. In males, the ciliary dysfunction extends to the sperm flagella, leading to abnormal sperm motility, which is a primary cause of infertility in these patients despite normal sperm count. The immotile sperm cannot effectively reach and fertilize the ovum, causing infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypogonadism: Hypogonadism involves inadequate production of testosterone or sperm and is characterized by low sperm count or absent sperm production, often accompanied by decreased libido and erectile dysfunction. This is not a feature of Kartagener's syndrome, which presents with normal spermatogenesis but impaired motility.

 

Option B. Blockage of the vas deferens: Blockage of the vas deferens leads to obstructive azoospermia, where sperm cannot be transported out of the testicles. This is a common feature of cystic fibrosis rather than Kartagener’s syndrome and does not account for the normal sperm count with poor motility seen here.

 

Option D. Genetic mutation affecting spermatogenesis: While genetic mutations can affect spermatogenesis directly, causing abnormal or decreased sperm production, this does not fit the scenario of Kartagener's syndrome, where sperm production is normal but motility is impaired due to dysfunctional ciliary movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener's syndrome, part of primary ciliary dyskinesia, leads to infertility primarily due to abnormal sperm motility caused by defective ciliary and flagellar movement. Patients commonly present with respiratory symptoms and situs inversus due to similar ciliary dysfunction in respiratory epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells

 

  • The layer marked as D is stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are not present in stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are predominantly present in stratum spinosum.
  • Keratinocytes, Merkel cells & Melanocytes are all seen in Stratum Basale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocytes: Keratinocytes are the most prevalent cells in the epidermis and are definitely found in the stratum basale. They are responsible for the production of keratin, a key structural protein in the skin.

 

Option B. Merkel cells: Merkel cells are mechanoreceptor cells that are present in the basal layer of the epidermis. They are involved in the sensation of light touch.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are also present in the stratum basale. These cells produce melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color and provides protection against UV radiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.4

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder. The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature. Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D. Delusional disorder: The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Hypereosinophilic syndrome is a condition characterized by an abnormally high count of eosinophils in the blood for a minimum of 6 months, without any apparent underlying cause, and with involvement of the heart, nervous system, or bone marrow. What is the minimum eosinophil count required for this diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. >1500/mm³

 

Explanation:

 

Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) is defined by a persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in the blood for at least six months. The diagnostic criteria for HES stipulate that the eosinophil count should be equal to or greater than 1500 cells per cubic millimeter (mm³) of blood.

 

This elevated eosinophil count can cause damage to various organs, leading to a range of symptoms and complications. These can include heart problems (cardiomyopathy), digestive issues (gastroenteritis), skin abnormalities, sinus inflammation, lung inflammation, nerve damage, and blood vessel inflammation. Some individuals may also experience blood clots, enlargement of the liver and spleen, and other blood cell abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. >500/mm³: This eosinophil count, while elevated, is not high enough to meet the diagnostic threshold for HES.

 

Option B. >1000/mm³: Similar to option a, this count is elevated but falls below the required level for diagnosing HES.

 

Option D. >2000/mm³: While this indicates a significant increase in eosinophils, the definitive criterion for HES is an eosinophil count of 1500/mm³ or higher.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of hypereosinophilic syndrome hinges on the presence of a persistently elevated eosinophil count of 1500/mm³ or more for a minimum of 6 months, along with signs of organ damage attributable to eosinophils, and the absence of an identifiable cause for the increased eosinophil levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Agranulocytosis.

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine. Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by a dangerously low level of neutrophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood. Neutrophils are crucial for fighting infection, so their reduction significantly increases the risk of serious infections. Patients on clozapine are closely monitored with regular blood tests to detect this condition early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Akathisia: This is a condition characterized by a feeling of inner restlessness and an inability to stay still. It is a common side effect of typical antipsychotics but it is unlikely to be seen with clozapine.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: While antipsychotics can have sedating effects, respiratory depression is not commonly associated with clozapine.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: This is not typically associated with clozapine. Hyperthermia can occur with neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a rare but serious side effect of typical antipsychotics in general. It is not associated with the use of clozapine.


Educational Objective:

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine, requiring regular monitoring of white blood cell counts to ensure early detection and prevention of serious infections.

choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left atrium

 

In the case of mitral stenosis (MS), the obstruction at the mitral valve leads to increased pressure in the left atrium as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve. This increased pressure causes the left atrium to dilate. This dilation can be identified on a chest X-ray as enlargement of the left atrial silhouette. The left atrium enlargement is often the earliest and most prominent cardiac chamber change seen in mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Right atrium enlargement generally occurs later in the course of mitral stenosis as a consequence of the elevated pressure being transmitted back through the lungs to the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle is typically not directly affected by mitral stenosis, as this condition primarily impacts the left atrium. Left ventricular enlargement would be more characteristic of conditions affecting the left ventricular outflow or volume overload.

 

Option D. Right ventricle: Right ventricular enlargement may eventually occur if the disease progresses to the point of causing pulmonary hypertension, which then puts a strain on the right ventricle. However, this is a later development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis.
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
     

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter

 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

 

The correct sequence of events during vomiting is:

 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: This begins the vomiting process, moving contents from the ileum towards the stomach.

 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: This allows the contents to move from the small intestine into the stomach.

 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach: These contractions help to force the stomach contents upwards.

 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis: This involves taking a deep breath with the glottis closed, increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

 

1. LES is open and UES is closed: Initially, the LES opens to allow the contents to move into the esophagus, while the UES remains closed.

 

5. LES opens and UES opens: Finally, both sphincters open to allow the contents to be expelled through the mouth.

 

Act of vomiting involves series of movements that takes place in GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sequence of events in act of vomiting:

 

  1. Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  2. Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  3. Closure of glottis
  4. Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  5. Elevation of soft palate
  6. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  7. Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  8. Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  9. Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conditioned pain modulation: This refers to the phenomenon where pain in one part of the body can reduce pain in another part, which is not directly related to the mechanism of TENS.

 

Option C. Descending inhibition: While TENS does activate descending inhibitory pathways, the primary mechanism described in the context of TENS for this question is the gate control theory.

 

Option D. Central inhibition: This refers to the inhibition of pain at the level of the central nervous system, which is a broader concept and not specific to the primary mechanism of TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Of the given statements regarding trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica is seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Fasciola hepatica is the largest and most common liver fluke found in man

 

Habitat - The parasite resides in the liver and biliary passages of the definitive host.

 

Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle and man.

 

Intermediate host: Snails

 

Mode of infection: The definitive host, sheep and man, get infection by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

 

Life cycle-

 

 

Unlike other trematodes and basically all other flatworms, the schistosomes are dioecious, i.e., the sexes are separate

 

Schistosoma – Cercariae penetrates through skin, eggs with terminal spine, only snails as intermediate hosts and separate sexes.

 

Praziquantel remains the drug of choice for all trematode infections except fascioliasis, for which triclabendazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma are monoecious: This statement is false. Schistosomes are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes (male and female), which is an exception among trematodes, as most are hermaphroditic.

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water: This statement is false. Fasciola hepatica infection is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation, not directly through contaminated water.

 

Option D. Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections: This statement is false. While triclabendazole is the drug of choice for fascioliasis, praziquantel remains the drug of choice for most other trematode infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

The carotid body chemoreceptors play a crucial role in monitoring and responding to changes in blood oxygen levels, particularly during labor and delivery. These receptors are highly sensitive to decreases in blood oxygen levels (hypoxia) and increases in carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia). When activated, they send signals to the brainstem to increase respiratory rate and heart rate, thereby ensuring adequate oxygen supply to the fetus.

 

During labor, the fetus can experience transient periods of hypoxia due to contractions and reduced placental blood flow. The carotid body chemoreceptors detect these changes and contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration, which is an important indicator of fetal well-being.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Incorrect. Aortic baroreceptors are primarily involved in regulating blood pressure by detecting changes in arterial pressure and activate cardio-vagal (Parasympathetic) center. Their activation leads to reduction in fetal heart rate (not acceleration).

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: Incorrect. While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall cardiovascular regulation, the direct response to hypoxia and resulting heart rate acceleration is mediated by chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): Incorrect. ANP is involved in regulating blood volume and pressure by promoting sodium and water excretion, but it does not directly influence fetal heart rate acceleration during labor.

 

Educational Objective

 

Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement 2 years ago presents to the emergency department with fever, fatigue, and a new heart murmur. He reports intermittent chills and night sweats for the past 3 weeks. Physical examination reveals splinter hemorrhages on his fingernails and a 2/6 diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Blood cultures are positive, and an echocardiogram shows a vegetation on the prosthetic aortic valve. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Streptococcus viridans

 

Explanation:

 

Streptococcus viridans is the most common cause of late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), which occurs more than 12 months after valve replacement. This organism is often implicated because it commonly colonizes the oral cavity and can enter the bloodstream during dental procedures or other transient bacteremias, leading to infection of the prosthetic valve. Unlike early PVE, late PVE resembles native valve endocarditis and frequently involves viridans group streptococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus epidermidis
Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS), is the leading cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis, typically occurring within the first 2 months post-surgery. Its association with early infection is due to contamination during surgery, and it is less likely to cause late-onset PVE.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus
Staphylococcus aureus can cause both early and late prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially in patients with intravenous drug use or healthcare-associated exposures. However, it is more frequently associated with early PVE or acute, aggressive presentations rather than the subacute symptoms seen in this case.

 

Option D. Enterococcus faecalis
Enterococcus faecalis can cause prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially in patients with a history of gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures. However, it is less commonly involved than Streptococcus viridans in late PVE and is more often seen in early or healthcare-associated infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosthetic valve endocarditis occurring more than 12 months after valve replacement is most commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans, reflecting its similarity to native valve endocarditis. Recognizing the timeline and the typical pathogens associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.
